excerpt: An Archive of Our Own, a project of the Organization for Transformative Works
description:
Chapters: 1/1
Fandom: Critical Role (Web Series)
Rating: Teen And Up Audiences
Warnings: Major Character Death
Relationships: The Mighty Nein - Relationship, Vox Machina - Relationship
Characters: Vax'ildan (Critical Role), Caduceus Clay, Fjord (Critical Role), Caleb Widogast, Mollymauk Tealeaf, Yasha (Critical Role), Jester Lavorre, Beauregard (Critical Role), Nott (Critical Role)
Additional Tags: Canon Compliant, Canonical Character Death, Team as Family, Ghosts, sort of ghosts, Listen I really love Vax okay, Canon-Typical Violence, Canon-typical swearing
Summary:

‘The Mighty Nein were being haunted. And it took them far to long to work it out.’
Snippets in time in which the Mighty Nein interact with the being who is 'haunting’ them and how they deal with that.

tags: people who are 16 or 17 might not realize
summary: If you haven’t seen This Animatic (“The Fire” art by galo, video by kuutti), I highly recommend it as a audio/visual...
body:
If you haven’t seen This Animatic (“The Fire” art by galo, video by kuutti), I highly recommend it as a audio/visual representation of Caleb’s backstory. It’s only a minute, but it’s been on my mind since I watched it. 

At first I thought it was because the song lyrics (from “We Have It All” by Pim Stones) were so perfect, but it hit me that what really makes this art work and punch the viewer in the feels is that the artist correctly conveys just how young Bren, Astrid, and Eodwulf were. Sometimes art of the BlumenTrio doesn’t lean into the fact that they were 16/17, but this one pulls no punches.

reblog.comment:

Sometimes art of the BlumenTrio doesn’t lean into the fact that they were 16/17, but this one pulls no punches.

If you haven’t seen This Animatic (“The Fire” art by galo, video by kuutti), I highly recommend it as a audio/visual representation of Caleb’s backstory. It’s only a minute, but it’s been on my mind since I watched it.

Sometimes art of the BlumenTrio doesn’t lean into the fact that they were 16/17, but this one pulls no punches.
trail.content:
If you haven’t seen This Animatic (“The Fire” art by galo, video by kuutti), I highly recommend it as a audio/visual representation of Caleb’s backstory. It’s only a minute, but it’s been on my mind since I watched it.

Sometimes art of the BlumenTrio doesn’t lean into the fact that they were 16/17, but this one pulls no punches.

summary: The thing about Bertrand Bell is, everything about him screams “Gilderoy Lockhart” but he’s actually level 18. He is...
body: The thing about Bertrand Bell is, everything about him screams “Gilderoy Lockhart” but he’s actually level 18. He is ridiculously powerful. He has real skills. Skills that the vast majority of people, even really accomplished people, don’t have. So, as boastful and clearly inexperienced in Pandemonium as he is, he actually must be a pretty successful adventurer.

reblog.comment: The thing about Bertrand Bell is, everything about him screams “Gilderoy Lockhart” but he’s actually level 18. He is ridiculously powerful. He has real skills. summary: I’m so into Nott/Jester as a ship, I can’t believe. Like, I definitely adore Yeza and want Yeza, Nott and Luc to be happy...

I’m so into Nott/Jester as a ship, I can’t believe.

Like, I definitely adore Yeza and want Yeza, Nott and Luc to be happy forever.

But also… Fluffernutter is too powerful.

summary: A little out of blue, but what do you think Tori was like and what do you hope she was like?
question: A little out of blue, but what do you think Tori was like and what do you hope she was like?
answer:
Based on what we know of Beau’s preferences based on the types of women she tends to flirt with—namely: older than her, somewhat-to-very authoritative, and often buff—I would imagine Tori broadly fits in that range. Especially given that she “showed Beau the ropes” (a statement which I am interpreting broadly…) 

It’s somewhat unclear whether Beau worked with any established guilds, or if she just kind of…freelanced, as it were. But assuming Beau was loosely a part of some organization, I’d assume Tori was mid-to-high ranking within it. As far as “older” goes—since we don’t really know what age she and Tori met, I think the age difference could be anywhere from 2-10 years (with 4-6 being where I’d place it if I end up writing them at all). 

Though I really hope Beau is wrong about Tori hating her for something that was ultimately her father’s fault, the fact that she’s concerned about it makes me think that Tori was probably pretty no-nonsense and maybe a bit ruthless, especially in the face of betrayal. I’ve also been picturing her as kind of a butch handy-gay. Whatever the D&D gay culture equivalent of having your keys on a carabiner is, Tori is that.

The biggest indication we got that Beau has had some experience with a romantic relationship before we learned about Tori, was her reaction to Jester thinking that romance/smut books are what love is “really like.” With the benefit of hindsight her reaction suggests that her relationship with Tori wasn’t only sexual, and I think it implies that Beau’s romantic feelings were probably at least somewhat reciprocated. I’d really like to hope that Tori was soft, in some way. While I don’t think any of that’s unlikely, I do think that Tori is liable to be abrasive in a similar way that Beau is on the surface. Based off what Beau seems to appreciate about her friends, but also about people like Dairon, I imagine that Tori was generally pretty supportive and accepting of her in a way that would have felt singular for Beau at the time. 

Mostly I hope that if Beau ends up meeting Tori again that it gets to be a moment of healing and reconciliation for the both of them. Of all of the specific details we’ve learned about Beau’s backstory, this bit has been the part that made me hate Beau’s father the most, because he managed to take away the one thing in her life that seemed to be genuinely good and make her feel like it was somehow her fault. I’d like to hope that Tori would know who the right person to blame in that situation was, even if she might understandably have her own conflicted feelings about the situation.

But, as a matter of exceptional goodwill, I will accept Keg as a replacement for the duration of Yasha’s absence.
